Therefore, they looked for reasons to cover their hearts by saying that it was impossible for Allah to appoint a messenger from the ordinary human race. If Allah appointed a messenger, then that messenger would be from the group of angels.
text.15:
In this verse, Allah explains the condition of the people of 'Ad who were afflicted by Allah's punishment and their attitude towards the call of the messenger sent to them. It is explained that the people of 'Ad were arrogant, feeling that no one could match them, and that everyone was subservient to them. Therefore, they disobeyed the Lord who created them and bestowed blessings upon them, and they did not accept the call of the Messenger of Allah sent to them. They challenged anyone who could match them.

Allah threatens and warns them by saying whether they have truly thought about what they are saying, and whether they do not know who they are opposing? The One they are opposing is Allah, the Almighty, who created everything including themselves, the All-Powerful, who is stronger than them. If Allah wills, then He can inflict any disaster upon them, and they will not be able to avoid that disaster in the slightest.

They actually knew and believed in the proofs of Our greatness and power, which were conveyed by the messengers sent to them. However, they denied it and disobeyed the messengers.
text.16:
In this verse, Allah explains the form of punishment inflicted upon the people of 'Ad. He sent a fierce, extremely cold wind accompanied by a roaring sound that destroyed them. This fierce, extremely cold wind continuously struck them for seven nights and eight days, which were days of misfortune for them, as explained in Allah's words:

"And as for 'Ad, they were destroyed by a furious wind, exceedingly violent, which He imposed upon them for seven nights and eight days in succession, so that you could see the people therein fallen as if they were hollow trunks of palm trees." (al-Haqqah/69: 6-7)

It is explained in this verse that the purpose of Allah inflicting this terrible punishment upon the people of 'Ad was so that they would feel the consequences of their arrogance and pride towards Allah and the messengers sent to them, namely humiliation, degradation, and the calamities that befell them in their worldly life. And the punishment of the Hereafter is more severe and extremely humiliating for them. They will not find any helper who can free them from that punishment.
text.17:
To the people of Thamud, Allah conveyed His religion through the Prophet Saleh. Allah showed them the path of salvation and the straight path, by displaying signs of His greatness and power that exist in this vast horizon. Allah also taught them laws that could bring them happiness in this world and the hereafter. However, they prioritized disbelief over faith, which also meant they prioritized humiliation and misery over glory and happiness. Because of their attitude and actions, Allah sent down upon them a punishment in the form of a loud, thunderous sound from the sky.

In another verse, Allah explains the punishment inflicted upon the people of Thamud. Allah says:

"Then the (awful) Cry overtook those who did wrong, and they lay (dead), prostrate in their homes, As if they had never lived there. No doubt! Thamud denied their Lord! No doubt! Away with Thamud!" (Hud/11: 67-68)
text.18: Prophet Saleh and the believers were saved by Allah from that torment. They were not afflicted by that terrible calamity and disaster because of their faith and piety towards Him.
text.19: This verse explains Allah's command to the Prophet Muhammad to convey to those who disbelieve their state on the Day of Judgment. On that day, all the enemies of Allah and those who disbelieve in Him will be gathered in Hell. They will be driven into it like people herding and driving livestock. Not a single one of them will escape or be left behind.
text.20: When they arrive at the edge of Hell, they will be questioned about the deeds they committed during their lives in the world. As witnesses to the deeds they have done will be all their body parts that directly committed those sinful acts, such as their ears, eyes, and other parts of their bodies. Each creature will be questioned according to its condition and nature. What is asked and how those creatures answer, including knowledge of the unseen (ghaib), is known only to Allah. Perhaps there will be questions related to their intentions and the contents of their hearts, or about their actions. If the questions are about obedience in worship, good manners, maintaining ties of kinship (silaturrahim), righteous deeds (amal saleh), and things similar to that, and they are presented to people who were fond of doing those things during their lives, then surely those people will answer them joyfully to Allah. If bad character, severing ties of kinship, evil deeds, and other actions similar to that, are presented to those who committed them, then surely they will answer with trembling and fear. Allah knows best about that.
text.21:
When hearing and seeing that their own skin testified against their deeds, the disbelievers reproached their skin, saying, "Why do you testify against us, when you were the ones who helped and encouraged us to commit sins during our lives in the world?" Their skins replied, "Allah, the Almighty, has made us able to speak, so that we can clearly and completely explain everything you commanded us to do." Allah says:

This day We will seal over their mouths, and their hands will speak to Us, and their feet will testify about what they used to earn. (Yasin/36: 65)

Regarding the questioning and testimony in the Hereafter, it is explained in a hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) narrated from Anas bin Malik, who said:

When we were with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), he laughed and said, "Do you know why I am laughing?" We replied, "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said, "I am laughing because of the conversation between a servant and his Lord (on the Day of Judgment). The servant says, 'O my Lord, did You not protect me from injustice?'" The Messenger of Allah said, "The Lord says, 'Indeed.'" The Messenger of Allah said, "The servant says, 'Then I do not allow anyone to testify against me except from myself.'" The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Allah says, 'Sufficient is yourself as a witness against your own deeds today, and the testimony of the angels who record.'" The Messenger of Allah said, "Then the mouth of that person is sealed, and it is said to his limbs, 'Speak,' so the limbs explain his deeds." The Messenger of Allah said, "Then that person is allowed to speak to his limbs." The Prophet said, "Then the servant says (to his limbs), 'Woe and destruction be upon you all. I was striving to defend you.'" (Narrated by Muslim and Ibn Hibban)

Allah explains that He is the One who created mankind for the first time, from non-existence to existence, and He is also the One who made clear signs for them. If Allah was able to create mankind for the first time, then surely He is able to repeat that creation a second time, by resurrecting mankind after their death, then He will recompense all of mankind's deeds with justice.
text.22:
It is narrated from al-Bukhari and Muslim, along with other imams, from Ibn Mas'ud who said, "When I was hiding behind the curtain of the Ka'bah, three people came: one Quraysh and two Bani Thaqif, or one Bani Thaqif and two Quraysh, with very little knowledge and very large bellies. They uttered words that I had never heard. One of them said, 'Do you think that Allah hears our words?' The other replied, 'Indeed, if we raise our voices, He will hear us, and if we do not raise them, He will not hear us.' Then the other said, 'If He hears something from it, He must hear all of it.'" Then Ibn Mas'ud conveyed this to the Prophet saw, and Allah revealed this verse until His saying: *mi nal khasirin.*

This verse explains that humans cannot hide and conceal their vile deeds, even if they commit disobedience, evil, and disbelief openly and deny the Day of Resurrection and Allah's retribution. In fact, they think that while they hide their actions from humans, Allah does not know what they do. Therefore, He will not be able to punish and give retribution.

This verse warns believers to always be vigilant and think carefully about the actions they will take, because Allah knows everything they do, and nothing is hidden from Him.
text.23:
The disbelievers' assumption that Allah does not know and does not see the evil deeds they commit is a bad assumption. Such an assumption will lead to the courage to commit forbidden acts, resulting in harm to themselves. As a result of such an assumption, they will suffer loss and humiliation in this world and a painful torment in the Hereafter.

From this verse, it can be understood that a good assumption is to believe that Allah knows all the deeds of His servants, from the subtle to the great, from the visible to the hidden, and Allah knows all the contents of their hearts.

If a person believes this, then he will always examine everything he is about to do, what is pleasing to Allah and what is not. He will stop and distance himself from all actions that are not pleasing to Allah, because he is convinced that Allah sees and knows all his actions.

Narrated by Ahmad, Muslim, Abu Dawud, and Ibn Majah from Jabir bin 'Abdullah:

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "You should never die except while having good thoughts about Allah." (Narrated by Ahmad, Muslim, Abu Dawud, and Ibn Majah)

The scholars are of the opinion that there are two kinds of assumptions: first, a good assumption, which is to assume that Allah has mercy, virtue, and goodness that He will bestow upon mankind, as mentioned in the Hadith Qudsi:

Allah says, "I am as My servant thinks of Me." (Narrated by Muslim from Anas)

Second, a bad assumption, which is to assume that Allah does not know all the deeds of His servants.

According to Qatadah, there are two kinds of assumptions, namely: first, an assumption that saves, as explained in Allah's words:

Indeed, I was certain that I would be meeting my account. (al-Haqqah/69: 20)

And Allah's words:

(Those who are certain) that they will meet their Lord, and that to Him they will return. (al-Baqarah/2: 46)

Second, an assumption that destroys, as explained in this verse of Allah.

Umar bin Khaththab said about this verse, "They are the people who continuously commit sins, do not repent from those deeds, and they argue about the forgiveness of God, so that they leave the world with nothing." Then Umar recited this verse.

Al-hasan al-Bashri said, "Indeed, a people were deceived by their empty fantasies until they died, and they did not have any good deeds. One of them said, 'Indeed, I have good thoughts about my Lord.' Indeed, he has lied. If his assumption was good, then his deeds would also be good." Then Al-hasan al-Bashri read this verse.
text.24:
In this verse, Allah explains the state of those who have evil thoughts about Allah, namely that they will be cast into Hell. All of them are cast into Hell without exception, and this Hell is their final destination.

If any of them were to ask for the punishment to be postponed or ask for forgiveness from Allah and be willing to return to the world if Allah gave them the opportunity, then none of it would be granted. Their requests cannot possibly be granted because they have left the world. The place for good deeds and the world have been destroyed, while the Hereafter is not a place for good deeds, but a place to receive the results of one's deeds during their life in the world.
text.25:
Allah explains that He has prepared for the disbelievers companions and helpers in the form of devils from among the jinn and mankind. They consider worldly actions that lead to misguidance and disbelief to be good, such as indulging in desires, loving to accumulate wealth solely for personal gain, being power-hungry, committing acts of disobedience and forbidden things, and so on. Similarly, with matters of the afterlife, the devils have instilled in people's hearts the belief that there is no heaven or hell, no life after death, no resurrection and reckoning, no God who must be worshipped, and so on. Therefore, it is easy for them to do the things they want and commit forbidden acts. Allah says:

"And whoever turns away from the remembrance of the Most Merciful - We appoint for him a devil, and he is to him a companion. And indeed, they avert them from the [right] way while they think that they are guided." (az-Zukhruf/43: 36-37)

Because of their attitudes and actions, punishment is decreed for them, like the punishment that was inflicted upon previous nations who followed the deceptions of the devils. All of them, that is, the devils and their followers, suffer the same loss and destruction. They will all receive a painful punishment in the Hereafter because they are all people who harm themselves.
text.26:
Those who disbelieve and deny Allah and His Messenger said to their people, "Never listen to the verses of the Qur'an recited by Muhammad, do not pay attention to and contemplate its contents. You should try to disrupt the hearing of those who listen to it, such as by singing, cheering. With your attitude like that, hopefully those who hear it will not clearly understand the recitation of the Qur'an that they hear."

In the past, when the Messenger of Allah was still in Mecca, before migrating to Medina, when he recited the verses of the Qur'an, he raised his voice so that many people could hear it. When the young polytheists of Mecca heard him reciting the Qur'an, they drove away those who listened to the Prophet's recitation by saying, "Disturb Muhammad's voice by crying, whistling, singing, or clapping your hands."

Ibn 'Abbas said that Abu Jahl said to his people, "When Muhammad recites the verses of the Qur'an, shout loudly in front of him, so that what he says cannot be heard." In fact, Allah commands to listen when the Qur'an is recited. His word:

And when the Qur'an is recited, then listen to it and be silent, that you may receive mercy. (al-A'raf/7: 204)
text.27: In this verse, Allah threatens the disbelievers with a painful torment, saying, "We will truly cause the disbelievers to taste a torment the severity of which cannot be described, and We will recompense them for all the sins and prohibitions they have committed. We will not reward them for all the good deeds they have done, because all good deeds such as maintaining kinship ties, helping the afflicted, performing good deeds, and so on, have been erased by their disbelief. They cannot expect anything from those good deeds except for bad deeds."
text.28:
The recompense for those who mock the verses of Allah and for His enemies is the fire of Hell. They will abide therein forever, and they will continuously feel the torment. They will no longer be able to escape it.

Then Allah explains that they will be in Hell, abiding therein forever, as a recompense for their actions of denying the verses of Allah when they were in the world.
text.29:
In this verse, it is explained that when the disbelievers feel the torment of hell, they ask Allah to bring forth the devils who misled them. This request is made so that they can vent their anger. They say, "Our Lord, bring forth to us the devils who misled us, so that we can vent our resentment upon them by trampling on their bodies."

In other verses, it is explained that some of these devils are from the jinn and some are from mankind, as Allah says:

And thus We have appointed for every prophet an enemy - devils from mankind and jinn... (al-An'am/6: 112)

And Allah says:

Who whispers [evil] into the breasts of mankind - From among the jinn and mankind. (an-Nas/114: 5-6)
text.30:
This verse explains that those who say and acknowledge that the God Who Creates, Sustains, and Maintains life, Provides sustenance, and Who alone deserves to be worshipped, is only the One and Only God, and then remain steadfast in their belief, then the angels will descend to accompany them in times of need. Among these times are when they die, in the grave, and when they are judged in the Hereafter, so that all the difficulties they face feel lighter.

In a hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (saw) it is explained that steadfastness in belief is very necessary for a believer:

Sufyan bin 'Abdullah ats-Tsaqafi narrated that a person said, "O Messenger of Allah, command me about Islam with a command that I will not ask anyone other than you." The Messenger of Allah replied, "Say: I believe in Allah, then be steadfast." I said, "What should I guard?" Then the Messenger of Allah pointed to his tongue. (Narrated by Muslim)

According to Abu Bakr, what is meant by the word "istiqamah" is not associating partners with Allah in anything.

To those who believe and are steadfast in their belief by not associating partners with Him, Allah sends down angels who deliver glad tidings, provide all that is beneficial, ward off harm, and eliminate any sorrow that may befall them in all worldly and otherworldly affairs. Thus, their hearts become open and peaceful, and there is no anxiety within them. As for the disbelievers, the devils come and constantly tempt them, making evil deeds appear beautiful in their eyes.

Waki' and Ibn Zaid are of the opinion that the angels give good news to those who believe in three states, namely, when dying, in the grave, and at the time of resurrection.

To those who believe, the angels say that they do not need to worry about facing the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Reckoning. They also do not need to grieve over worldly matters that have escaped them, such as those related to family, children, wealth, and so on.

According to 'Atha', what is meant by "alla takhafu wa la tahzanu" is: do not worry that Allah will not reward your deeds, indeed you are accepted by Allah, and do not grieve over the sins you have committed, for indeed Allah forgives them.

This verse further explains that the angels tell the believers to rejoice in the Paradise that the messengers have promised. They will surely enter Paradise and abide therein forever.
text.31:
Furthermore, the angels declared to the believers that they always accompany and help them in all worldly affairs. The angels always provide guidance that leads to goodness, truth, and benefit. Likewise, the angels will be with the believers in the Hereafter, accompanying them in the grave, on the Day of Judgment, and the Day of Reckoning until they enter Paradise.

Some commentators are of the opinion that the one who declares to the believers in this verse is Allah Himself, so the meaning of this verse is: "And Allah is the Wali (Guardian, Protector) of those who believe who are steadfast..."

The angels say that in Paradise, the believers will obtain all kinds of pleasures, happiness, and delights that are always longed for, as well as everything that is desired and requested.
text.32: In this verse, it is explained that Allah bestows such things as a grace for them. He forgives all their sins and pours out mercy upon them.
text.33:
This verse censures those who say untrue things about the Qur'an. The Qur'an questions: what speech is better than the Qur'an, and who is better in speech than one who invites people to obey Allah?

Ibn Sirin, as-Suddi, Ibn Zaid, and al-Hasan are of the opinion that the person with the best speech is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). When reading this verse, al-Hasan said that what is meant is the Messenger of Allah, he is the beloved and the wali (friend/protector) of Allah. He is the one sanctified by Allah and is His chosen one. He is the inhabitant of the earth who loves Allah the most. Allah answers his call and he invites people to follow that call. Some other scholars are of the opinion that this verse has a general meaning, namely all those who invite others to obey Allah. The Messenger of Allah is included among those with the best speech, because he invites people to the religion of Allah.

This verse explains that a person is said to be the best when his speech contains three things, namely:

1. An invitation to others to follow the religion of Tawhid, to single out Allah and obey Him.

2. An invitation to do good deeds, to obediently carry out the commands of Allah and stop His prohibitions.

3. Making Islam as a religion and purifying obedience only to Allah alone.

By explaining the best speech, it is as if Allah is affirming to the Messenger of Allah that the task given to him is the most noble task. Therefore, he is asked to continue carrying out da'wah (invitation to Islam), and to be patient in facing the difficulties and obstacles carried out by the disbelievers.

From this verse it is understood that the most important thing to be done by a Muslim is to improve oneself first, by strengthening faith in the heart, obeying all the commands of Allah, and stopping all His prohibitions. After oneself is improved, invite others to follow the religion of Allah. A person whose soul is pure, whose faith is strong, and who always does good deeds, his invitation is more heeded by people, because he invites others with strong conviction and with a firm voice, without hesitation.
text.34:
This verse explains that good deeds that are pleasing to Allah and rewarded are not the same as evil deeds that He hates, and those who commit them will certainly be punished.

This verse can be interpreted as stating that the *da'wah* (call, invitation) of those who call to Allah and follow Islam is not the same as the act of criticizing those who carry out that *da'wah*.

The attitude of the disbelievers who criticize the *da'i* (those who call to Islam) is explained in Allah's words:

¦ Our hearts are veiled from that to which you invite us¦ (Fushshilat/41: 5)

And Allah's words:

And those who disbelieve say, "Do not listen to this Qur'an and speak noisily during [its recitation] that perhaps you will overcome." (Fushshilat/41: 26)

With this verse, it is as if Allah is stating to the Messenger of Allah (saw) that if he does good, he will receive a reward of good in the form of appreciation during his life in this world and a great reward in the Hereafter. While the disbelievers who do evil will receive humiliation in this world, and in the Hereafter they will receive a painful punishment. The Messenger was also forbidden to repay their evil with evil. If he repaid evil with evil, they would certainly suffer multiple losses. Therefore, the Messenger was commanded to repay their evil with good.

Then Allah explains how to repay the evil of the disbelievers with good by commanding the Messenger to repay the ignorance and evil of the disbelievers in the best way, to repay their bad deeds with good deeds, to forgive their mistakes, and to face their anger with patience. If the Prophet did so, they would gradually evaluate their own actions and feel ashamed of their actions.

Allah explains the results that believers will obtain if they repay the bad deeds of the disbelievers with good deeds. Allah says that if the believers succeed in doing so, the enmity of the disbelievers towards them will certainly turn into friendship, and hatred will turn into love.

Ibn 'Abbas said that in this verse, Allah commands people to be patient when angry, gentle towards the ignorant, and to forgive people's mistakes. If someone does this, Allah will protect them from Satan, and their enemies will submit and obey them.

It is narrated that a man insulted Qunbur, the slave of 'Ali bin Abi Thalib, whom he had freed. 'Ali then called him and said, "O Qunbur, leave the person who insults you, let him be, may the Most Merciful Lord be pleased, and Satan become angry."

According to Muqatil, this verse was revealed in connection with Abu Sufyan. He was one of the greatest enemies of the Messenger of Allah. However, because of the Prophet's patience and good attitude towards him, Abu Sufyan became a close friend of the Prophet, establishing a relationship through marriage (*mushaharah*).
text.35:
In this verse, Allah explains the best way to deal with disbelievers, which is to be patient when suffering difficulties and hardships, to control anger, not to be vengeful, and to be forgiving.

Anas r.a., in interpreting this verse, said that what is meant by patience in this verse is that if someone is insulted by another person, he says, "If you insult me with a valid reason, may Allah forgive your sins. If you insult me with an invalid reason, may Allah forgive my sins."

Advice to be patient, control anger, and be forgiving of other people's mistakes is the most important and valuable advice. Only those who believe and do good deeds can accept this advice, and they will obtain happiness in this world and in the hereafter.

Qatadah said that the meaning of "great fortune" is Paradise (Jannah). The meaning of this verse is that patience is only bestowed upon those who will enter Paradise.
text.36: This verse explains that if Satan tempts you to retaliate evil with evil, then seek refuge in Allah from all the cunning of the accursed Satan. Allah is All-Hearing of your supplication and All-Knowing of everything Satan whispers into your heart.
text.37:
This verse explains that among the signs of Allah's greatness and power are the existence of night as a time for rest, day as a time for work and striving, the sun that emits its light, and the moon that shines. He is the One who regulates the movement of planets in their orbits in the sky, so that the calculation of years, months, days, and times is known, as Allah says:

"It is He who made the sun a shining light and the moon a derived light and determined for it phases - that you may know the number of years and accounts. Allah has not created this except in truth. He details the signs for a people who know." (Yunus/10: 5)

After Allah explains the signs of His greatness and power, He warns His servants never to prostrate to those signs of His greatness and power, such as the sun, moon, stars, and so on. Never glorify, worship, or consider them to have supernatural powers, because He alone created, controls, regulates, and determines their existence or non-existence.

It is as if this verse explains and reminds that humans are the most noble of God's creatures among all the creatures He has created. Therefore, it is not fitting for humans to glorify, consider sacred, and respect God's creatures that are lower than them. The One who deserves to be worshipped, glorified, and respected is the most powerful and most noble, namely Allah. If there are humans who worship and glorify creatures other than Allah, it means that humans have degraded their own dignity.

This verse also warns people who associate partners with Allah, idol worshippers, worshippers of the sun, moon, and stars, to realize their position among those other creatures.
text.38:
Then Allah warned Prophet Muhammad that if those polytheists who worship stars were arrogant and did not heed his call, then leave them to their misguided ways. Allah does not need them in the slightest. Whether they believe or do not believe is of no consequence to Allah whatsoever.

Allah continued His warning that the creatures who are in His presence are better than those polytheists; none of them are arrogant or boastful towards Him. They constantly glorify Him, pray day and night, and never feel weary in the slightest.

Allah says:

And you (Muhammad) will see the angels surrounding the Throne, glorifying their Lord with praise. And judgment will be passed among them in justice, and it will be said, "All praise is [due] to Allah, Lord of the worlds." (az-Zumar/39: 75)
text.39:
This verse explains that among the proofs of Allah's power to resurrect mankind on the Day of Judgment is the barren and dead earth, where no plants grow at all. However, when He waters that land with rainwater by channeling water to it, the earth transforms into green, because the soil becomes fertile and is overgrown with plants.

Allah says:

"And you see the earth barren, but when We send down rain upon it, it stirs [to life] and swells and produces [something] of every beautiful kind." (al-Hajj/22:5)

This verse relates to the growth of plants with the blessing of water sent down in the form of rain. A similar message can also be found in Surah al-Hajj/22 verse 5, which ends with the words: "...And you see the earth barren, but when We send down rain upon it, it stirs and swells and produces [something] of every beautiful kind." The words "stirs and swells" are associated with the movement of soil particles when plant seeds germinate and their roots develop and grow into mature trees.

Allah, who has revived the dead earth by pouring water on it, and brought plants to life, so that the earth turns green, is also able to revive the dead and able to resurrect them from the grave. None of this is difficult for Him. Everything is easy for Him. He is All-Powerful over all things.
text.40:
This verse explains that Allah is All-Knowing of everything done and the deceptions made by those who oppose the Qur'an according to their own desires, denying it and criticizing it. Nothing is hidden from Allah and nothing is unknown to Him. Therefore, He will recompense all their deeds with appropriate rewards.

Then Allah explains the difference and form of retribution that will be received by the believers and the disbelievers in the Hereafter, saying that those who are cast into Hell because they deny Allah, His Messenger, and His verses are not the same as those who believe in the verses of the Qur'an, follow His Messenger, and receive Paradise. Allah will establish a just decision between them, and the reward they will receive will certainly not be the same.

This verse is addressed to all people, both disbelievers and believers. However, some scholars are of the opinion that this verse has both a general and a specific meaning. The general meaning encompasses all people, both disbelievers and believers, while the specific meaning relates to Abu Jahl, who denied the Messenger of Allah (saw), and those who believed in him.

It was narrated by 'Abd ar-Razzaq, Ibn al-Mundhir, Ibn Asakir from Busyair bin Tamim, who said, "This verse was revealed concerning Abu Jahl and 'Ammar bin Yasir."

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the Prophet Muhammad already knows the consequences that those who commit sins will obtain in the Hereafter, and the consequences that those who believe will obtain in the future. Therefore, people are welcome to do whatever they wish; they already know the consequences. Allah sees all the deeds of mankind and gives recompense according to what they have done.
text.41:
In this verse, it is explained that the signs of those who disbelieve are their denial of Allah's verses and their denial of the Qur'an when it is conveyed to them. They will receive a reward commensurate with their disbelief.

Then Allah explains that the Qur'an is a noble book, whose contents cannot be invalidated and cannot be altered in the slightest.
text.42:
This verse affirms that nothing can nullify the verses of the Qur'an, not even the previous Books of Allah, such as the Torah, Psalms (Zabur), and Gospel (Injil), and no Book of Allah will come after the Qur'an. This meaning is in accordance with the opinion of Sa'id bin Jubair and al-Kalbi.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that the entire Qur'an is true, without any error whatsoever, because the Qur'an originates from Allah, the Lord of the Universe. Everything that originates from Allah is purely true, without anything lacking, erroneous, or imperfect. He is the All-Wise and the Most Praiseworthy.
text.43:
This verse is Allah's comfort to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) who was saddened by the attitude and actions of the polytheists towards the Qur'an he conveyed. Allah says that the attitudes, actions, and words of the polytheists who deny Allah's verses are similar to the actions and words conveyed by previous communities to their messengers. Nevertheless, they remained patient and steadfast in conveying their message. Therefore, Prophet Muhammad was also commanded to be patient and steadfast, like the previous messengers. He was also asked to remain firm in his call.

Another verse with the same meaning as this verse is His saying:

"Likewise, there did not come to those before them any messenger except that they said, "A magician or a madman." (adz-dzariyat/51: 52)

Some scholars of tafsir are of the opinion that the meaning of this verse is that what was conveyed to Prophet Muhammad, such as the teaching of the Oneness of Allah, and purifying obedience and submission only to Him, is the same as what was conveyed to the messengers who were sent before. This is natural because the religion of Allah has the same foundations and principles. All of them equally determine and command to devote oneself only to Allah, equally believe in the existence of the Day of Resurrection, and so on. If there are differences, then the differences are not related to the foundations or principles, but only related to *furu'* or what is not a principle. This is necessary because of differences in circumstances, time, and place.

This interpretation is in accordance with Allah's saying:

"Indeed, We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him..." (an-Nisa'/4: 163)

If this verse is connected with the verses that follow it, then the first opinion is more appropriate, because the discussion of the verses that follow is related to the attitude of the polytheists towards the Qur'an. But if it is connected with the previous verses, then the second opinion is appropriate, because the discussion is related to the Qur'an, as a revelation in which there are no errors or shortcomings. In interpretation, this verse is included in the group of verses that follow it.

At the end of this verse, it is explained to Prophet Muhammad that his Lord is the One and Only Lord. The One who deserves to be worshipped is also the Most Forgiving Lord to His servants who repent, and also gives a very painful punishment to the disbelievers who are arrogant and unwilling to repent.
text.44:
This verse is a response to the attitudes and statements of the polytheists found in the preceding verses. It is conveyed to them that if Allah had revealed the Qur'an to the Prophet Muhammad in a language other than Arabic, the Quraysh of Mecca would certainly say, "Why was the Qur'an not revealed in Arabic? So that we can easily understand the laws and provisions contained within it." Whereas previously they said, "Is the Qur'an that is revealed in a language other than Arabic, while the messenger who is sent is an Arab?"

Allah commands the Messenger of Allah to answer the questions of the polytheists who do not want to believe in the Qur'an by saying to them, "This Qur'an, for those who believe in it, believe that it comes from Allah the Almighty, and believe in the messenger who conveys it, is a guide to the path of happiness, a cure for the heart, and eliminates doubts." This verse is in line with Allah's saying:

"O mankind! There has come to you a good advice from your Lord (i.e. the Qur'an, enjoining all good and forbidding all evil), and a healing for that (disease of ignorance, doubt, hypocrisy and differences, etc.) which is in your breasts, - a guidance and a mercy (explaining lawful and unlawful things) for the believers." (Yunus/10: 57)

Those who do not believe in Allah, His Messenger, and the Qur'an, in their ears there are plugs that block their hearing from hearing the verses of the Qur'an. They are blind so that they cannot see the evidence of Allah's greatness and power and cannot receive the lessons conveyed by the Messenger.

Those who do not hear the verses of Allah and cannot see the evidence of His greatness and power are likened to someone who is called from a distant place, he can only hear a vague sound, so he does not understand the meaning of the sound.
text.45:
Furthermore, Allah conveys to Prophet Muhammad not to trouble himself because the people of Mecca disagreed about the Qur'an. Such a thing had also been done by previous communities to the messengers sent to them. Allah says that He had revealed the Torah to Moses, to be conveyed to the Children of Israel. They also disagreed about the Torah. Some affirmed it, and some denied it. Some believed in Moses, and some disbelieved in him. Therefore, Prophet Muhammad was commanded not to despair in conveying the religion of Allah, and to be patient in facing the actions of the disbelievers. The Prophet (saw) was also commanded to follow in the footsteps of the messengers who conveyed His religion.

Then Allah conveys that the disbelievers do not immediately receive punishment for their actions because the punishment is postponed until a specified time. This is in accordance with His decree that He postpones the punishment for the disbelievers until the Day of Judgment. If there were no such decree, Allah would have certainly decided their dispute with the believers.

Allah says:

"Nay, but the Hour is their appointed time (for due punishment), and the Hour will be more grievous and more bitter." (al-Qamar/54: 46)

And the word of Allah:

"And never think that Allah is unaware of what the wrongdoers do. He only delays them for a Day when eyes will stare (in horror)." (Ibrahim/14: 42)

Allah explains that the causes of destruction and punishment that befell the polytheists are because they were very doubtful and confused about the Qur'an. Because of their confusion and doubt, they denied it and did not heed the da'wah of the Messenger of Allah.
text.46:
At the end of this surah's verse, Allah explains the recompense that will be given for the deeds that humans perform. Whoever is obedient to Allah and His Messenger in this worldly life, carrying out His commands, and stopping His prohibitions, means he has strived to do good for himself by obtaining a great reward. Whoever disbelieves in Allah means he has strived to do evil for himself by obtaining a very painful torment in the Hereafter. A person is punished according to the deeds he has done; it is impossible for Allah to punish someone for the deeds of another.

Allah says:

"And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you of what you used to dispute." (al-An'am/6: 164)
text.47:
In this verse, Allah explains that knowledge of the Day of Judgment, its time, and how it will unfold is known only to Allah. Similarly, other unseen events, such as the successful emergence or spoilage of fruits from their calyxes, and the fetuses carried by mothers, whether they will be born normally or with physical defects, all of this is known with certainty only to Allah. Some things are indeed known to humans, such as the month when fruits will ripen, or when a baby is likely to be born, but this knowledge is very basic, not as detailed as Allah's knowledge, and not as complete as His statement.

In another verse, Allah affirms that only He knows the exact time of the Day of Judgment. Allah says:

"They ask you, [O Muhammad], about the Hour - when is its arrival? Say, "Its knowledge is only with my Lord. None will reveal its time except Him." (al-A'raf/7: 187)

The Prophet Muhammad saw himself, in a hadith narrated by 'Umar bin al-Khaththab, when asked by the Angel Gabriel about when the Day of Judgment would be, replied:

"Indeed, Gabriel asked the Messenger of Allah about the Day of Judgment, and the Messenger of Allah replied: 'The one asked does not know more than the one asking.'" (Narrated by Muslim from 'Umar bin al-Khaththab)

In the development of science today, many new things are known to humans, such as the time of the fruiting season for several kinds of fruits, the condition of the fetus in the womb such as gender, health, and when the fetus will be born. But this human knowledge is still very little compared to Allah's knowledge and is still an estimate, so it is not certain. This is different from Allah's knowledge, which is detailed and certain. Allah swt says:

"Allah knows what every female carries and what the wombs lose [of development] or exceed. And everything with Him is by due measure. (He is) Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, the Grand, the Exalted." (ar-Ra'd/13: 8-9)

It has been explained above that only Allah knows about the Day of Judgment and when it will occur. He knows all women who are pregnant and who give birth to children. From this explanation, it can be understood that Allah's knowledge includes things that are impossible for humans to know and things that humans may know if He gives His permission to them. Of course, there is wisdom and purpose in this, but only Allah knows with certainty the essence of that wisdom and purpose. Even if humans are given some of Allah's knowledge, the nature and form of that knowledge are not the same and differ from person to person.

Allah knows the contents of all women who are pregnant and who give birth. Allah's knowledge of women who are pregnant and who give birth is complete and certain knowledge, comprehensive down to the smallest detail. That knowledge is related to the process of the entire natural creation, from the past to the present and to the future.

It is different with the knowledge of an obstetrician regarding the pregnancy of a woman. He only knows in general terms, not in detail. In fact, his knowledge is limited and is merely an assumption, not certain knowledge, because certain and comprehensive knowledge is only with Allah.

Furthermore, Allah explains the events that will be experienced by the polytheists on the Day of Judgment. On that day, Allah will ask them firmly and clearly and demand their accountability for His partners whom they worshipped in the world; where they are now, why they are not together with those idols. Finally, the polytheists will answer with a firm answer, "O our Lord, we declare to You on this day that none of us acknowledges that You have partners; only You do we worship, there is no other."

Another verse of Allah with the same meaning as this verse:

"Then their only plea will be: "By Allah, our Lord, we were not polytheists." (al-An'am/6: 23)
text.48: This verse explains that on the Day of Judgment, the misguided polytheists will not see any benefit from the deities they worshipped in the world, that is, on the day they feel that all they did in the world was useless. No one will be able to save them from Allah's punishment. At that time, they will finally be convinced of the oneness and power of Allah, and they will also be convinced that there is no way out to avoid Allah's punishment.
text.49:
This verse explains the desires of humans to achieve things that concern their own interests. Most humans are greedy, fond of seeking wealth and pleasure for themselves.

They desire wealth and power, because according to them, with wealth and power, all their ideals and desires will be achieved. They want offspring, because with offspring they can bequeath all the wealth they have acquired and there will always be people who remember their services and successes during their life in the world. They want to acquire as much worldly possessions as possible, so they compete to achieve them, as if their lives and existence are spent on that.

In this verse, what humans always desire and seek is called "khair" (goodness). It is called "khair" because what humans desire is goodness which is the grace and favor of Allah. They make the grace and favor of Allah the goal to be achieved in their lives in this world, not as a tool or way that they can use to achieve something more noble and of higher value, so that the grace and favor of Allah, which was originally good, they turn into a source of disaster and calamity because of their lusts which can befall themselves or others.

What is meant by "seeking goodness" in this verse is desiring, striving, seeking, demanding and making goodness as a tool and way to achieve the goals of life in this world and the hereafter, not to seek goodness so that goodness can be used as a tool and way to achieve the goals desired by lust. Seeking goodness to fulfill the desires of lust can cause disaster for those who seek it. But, if seeking goodness is aimed at making goodness a tool and way to seek the pleasure of Allah, then seeking such goodness is encouraged by Islam.

For example, someone strives to seek lawful wealth so that with that wealth he can carry out his duties and obligations as a servant of Allah, such as providing for his family, giving charity in the way of Allah, helping the poor, and so on. Likewise, a person who wants to seek rank and power, he may seek it with the intention of upholding justice, upholding the laws of Allah, and helping those who are miserable. Such efforts are commendable and pleasing to Allah.

So, seeking goodness is essentially good if the goodness obtained is used as a tool and way to seek the pleasure of Allah. But, seeking goodness will destroy oneself if the goodness is used to fulfill one's lusts.

Another characteristic of humans is that if the goodness they seek is not obtained or they are struck by a disaster, then they become desperate, as if there is no hope for them, there is no more earth to stand on and no more sky to take shelter under, all that they desire seems to vanish. In such a state, they become despairing of the mercy of Allah and have bad thoughts about Allah as if Allah does not have the attribute of compassion and is not the Most Merciful to His servants.

The characteristics explained by this verse are the characteristics of people who do not believe and do not purify their obedience and submission to Allah. They still believe in the existence of other forces that can help them besides the power of Allah. As if they do not believe in His grace and favor and do not believe in the existence of true life, namely the life of the hereafter.

As for those who believe in Allah, they are those who are submissive and obedient to Him, feel His greatness and majesty and feel themselves dependent on His grace and favor. They believe in the existence of true life, namely life in the hereafter, and they believe that worldly life is only temporary. Therefore, they strive and work solely to seek His pleasure. They also believe that Allah tests His believing servants and that the test is always given in various forms, some in the form of misery and suffering, and some in the form of pleasure and wealth. Whatever the form of the test and trial, they face it with patience and tawakal. If they obtain goodness and wealth, they rejoice and are grateful to Him, and if they are struck by a disaster, they remain patient and steadfast, even drawing closer to Him. They continue to hope for the mercy and favor of Allah because they are truly certain of the attribute of Allah's compassion which pours out His mercy and favor on every servant who believes in Him. Allah swt says:

"O my sons! Go and enquire about Joseph and his brother, and never give up hope of Allah’s Mercy. Certainly no one despairs of Allah’s Mercy, except the people who disbelieve.” (Yusuf/12: 87)
text.50:
In this verse, Allah explains the characteristics of most people, which is that when they receive blessings and pleasures, they become forgetful and arrogant, declaring, "This is the result of my own work, so I don't need to give any of this wealth to others, and I don't need to be grateful to anyone. I am also not sure if the Day of Judgment will come?"

Furthermore, these disbelievers also state that if they are returned to Allah, then they will surely obtain goodness in His presence. This is how they think, unclearly and based only on assumptions. Therefore, this verse concludes with the affirmation that Allah will truly inform the disbelievers of what they did in the world and will inflict a painful punishment upon them in the Hereafter.

As for the characteristics of those who despair of Allah's mercy, they are as follows:

1. If the suffering and difficulties they are experiencing are suddenly removed from them, and then they are granted mercy and favor, they forget the suffering and hardship they once experienced, they forget the source of the mercy and favor they received, and they even say that everything they obtained was solely due to their own efforts and intelligence, not because of Allah's grace. The meaning of the phrase *hadha li* in this verse is: "This I obtained because of my own efforts and intelligence, therefore everything I obtained is truly mine and no one shares in this ownership with me." Therefore, I don't need to share it with others and I don't need to offer praise and gratitude to Allah and remember His grace and goodness.

2. They do not believe in the Day of Judgment. This disbelief arises from the arrogance and pride within them and because of the pleasures of life in this world that they are enjoying.

3. They say there is no reckoning, no Day of Recompense. According to them, if they are returned to Allah later, they will certainly obtain much goodness and pleasure as well.

At the end of this verse, Allah threatens the disbelievers who do not believe in the Day of Judgment, the Day of Recompense, and the existence of Paradise and Hell. Allah affirms that the disbelievers will truly experience the Day of Judgment. They will witness for themselves the evil deeds they once committed. Then Allah will weigh all that they have done and give a fitting reward for the evil deeds they have committed with a severe punishment in Hell.
text.51:
This verse explains that another bad trait of humans is that when they are given grace and blessings, they become engrossed in those graces and blessings. They become overly happy and joyful to the point that they forget the source of those graces and blessings. Sometimes, they even go further than that. They use those graces and blessings to challenge and destroy the religion of Allah: they create destruction on earth, severing ties of kinship with other people that Allah has commanded to be maintained. They feel they have become powerful people, so others under their power are obligated to respect and serve them. They have forgotten that they are humans who must act according to their nature, which is that they can only live with the help of other people and the help of the Most Helpful, Allah.

Conversely, if they are afflicted with misfortune or disaster, they remember Allah again. They pray to Allah while lying down, sitting, standing, walking, and in whatever state they are in. They even promise and swear by His name that if they are spared from the misfortune and disaster, they will become believers. In line with this verse, Allah says:

"And when affliction touches man, he calls upon Us, whether lying on his side or sitting or standing; but when We remove his affliction from him, he passes on as if he had never called upon Us for an affliction that touched him. Thus is made pleasing to the transgressors that which they have been doing." (Yunus/10: 12)
text.52:
This verse explains that in reality, the polytheists are in a state of doubt regarding the truth of the Qur'an and Muhammad SAW as the Messenger of Allah. Their state is between believing and denying. They acknowledge Muhammad SAW as a trustworthy, respected, and leading figure who can resolve problems that arise among the Quraysh tribes. Likewise, they admire the content and the high style of the Qur'an's language, which they believe is impossible for a human being to create. However, they are still influenced by the beliefs of their ancestors, and they are worried about the antipathy of their own people. If they declared what was in their hearts, they would certainly no longer be made leaders by their people; they would lose influence. This state of doubt is what constantly rages in their minds.

In such a state, Allah commands His Messenger to ask those misguided polytheists: "O polytheists, what do you think if the Qur'an is truly from Allah, while you deny its truth? If that is the case, then surely you are all among those who are misguided and distancing yourselves from the truth?" It is as if, with that question, Allah declares firmly that this very doubt will later lead them into the valley of misguidance and endless regret in the afterlife.
text.53:
This verse explains that the polytheists who doubted the Qur'an and the Messenger of Allah would see with their own eyes the proofs of the truth of Allah's verses in all corners of the world and within themselves. They saw and witnessed for themselves the Muslims in a weak and oppressed state while in Mecca, then the Messenger of Allah and his companions migrated to Medina, leaving behind their beloved homeland. While in Medina, the Messenger of Allah (saw) together with the Muhajirin and Ansar formed and built an Islamic society. This new society grew stronger and more developed over time. This was felt by the polytheists in Mecca, so they always tried to break this new strength as soon as possible. The strength of Islam and the Muslims was first felt by the Meccan polytheists during the Battle of Badr and then when they were scattered in the Battle of Khandaq. The last was when the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the Muslims conquered the city of Mecca without resistance from the polytheists. Finally, they witnessed people entering Islam in droves, including polytheists, their families, and their own friends. All of this was evidence of the truth of Allah's verses. Allah says:

When the victory of Allah has come and the conquest, And you see the people entering into the religion of Allah in multitudes, Then exalt [Him] with praise of your Lord and ask forgiveness of Him. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance. (an-Nasr/110: 1-3)

At the end of this verse, Allah reaffirms that He witnesses all the behavior of His servants, whether in the form of words, deeds, or actions, and He is All-Knowing of all that is in the hearts of men. He states that Muhammad (saw) is truthful, never lies, and everything he conveys is true. Allah says:

But Allah bears witness to that which He has revealed to you. He has sent it down with His knowledge. (an-Nisa'/4: 166)

Many people say that by studying nature, including ourselves, we can come to an understanding of the existence of God. Nature is a book waiting to be studied. However, God's hope in revealing the verse above is not always understood by humans. Surah Yunus/10: 101 is one of many verses that tell us that only scientists who have faith can understand God by studying nature.

Say, "Look at what is in the heavens and earth." But of no avail will be signs or warners to a people who do not believe. (Yunus/10: 101)
text.54:
This verse explains their doubts about the existence of the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment, because according to them, it is impossible for a person who has died to live again, and it is impossible for bodies that have been destroyed and mixed with the earth to be gathered, restored to their original state, and brought back to life. Because of this doubt, they are unable to pay attention to the truth of the Qur'an and the prophethood of Muhammad saw.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns the polytheists with a stern warning that He is All-Knowing of everything. Nothing escapes His knowledge. Therefore, He will give recompense with the utmost justice to His servants.
